introduction:
In this lesson, you will learn how to order food and drinks at restaurants. You will be introduced to simple vocabulary and basic sentence structures used when dining out.

Grammar Focus:

  • Simple Present Tense: Used for general statements (e.g., 'I want a coffee.')
  • Polite Requests: Using 'Can I have...?' or 'I would like...'
  • Yes/No Questions: (e.g., 'Do you have tea?')
  • Countable and Uncountable Nouns: (e.g., 'a sandwich' vs. 'some water')
presentation:
Vocabulary:

  • Menu
  • Waiter / Waitress
  • Order
  • Bill / Check
  • Dish
  • Drink
  • Starter / Appetizer
  • Main course
  • Dessert
  • Table for two
  • Reservation
  • Water (still/sparkling)
  • Coffee / Tea
  • Salad
  • Soup

Example Sentences:

  • 'Can I see the menu, please?'
  • 'We have a reservation for two.'
  • 'I would like to order a salad.'
  • 'Can I have the bill, please?'
  • 'I will have the main course and a drink.'

conclusion:
In this lesson, you learned how to order food and drinks at restaurants.

  • Key phrases include:
  • 'Can I see the menu, please?'
  • 'I would like to order... / I would like... / Can I have...?'
  • 'Can I have the bill, please?'

Example Dialogue:

Waiter: 'Hello! How can I help you?'
Customer: 'Hello! Can I see the menu, please?'
Waiter: 'Sure! Here you go.'
Customer: 'Thank you. I would like to order a salad and a coffee.'
Waiter: 'Anything else?'

Waiter: 'Of course. Here it is.'

Questions to Reinforce:

  • How do you ask for a menu politely?
  • What phrases can you use to order food?
  • How do you ask for the bill?

Homework:

Write a short dialogue between a waiter and a customer at a restaurant. Use at least five of the new vocabulary words or phrases you learned today.
